question_metadata.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?

responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS): A business model where software is deployed as a hosted service and accessed over the Internet. It involves hosting single-versioned software coupled with supplementary delivery and maintenance services, where clients are charged through recurring subscription fees on a pay-as-you-go basis. SaaS is outsourced software where both technology infrastructure and management (hardware, software and professional services) are contracted out to software vendors and accessed remotely.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Abstract: 'software-as-a-service (SaaS) has proliferated over the past decade and there are signs to suggest that this growth is likely to continue or even accelerate in the near future. By hosting single-versioned software coupled with supplementary delivery and maintenance services, SaaS vendors can effectively differentiate their product offerings from that of traditional on-premise software (TOPS)' | Page 1: 'Software-as-a-Service (SaaS), "software deployed as a hosted service and accessed over the Internet," is an emerging business model that is expected to grow rapidly' | Page 1: 'SaaS differs from traditional off-the-shelf software in three aspects. First, SaaS is outsourced software, meaning that both technology infrastructure and management - hardware, software and professional services - are contracted out to software vendors. Second, SaaS is remotely hosted, meaning that software are deployed as hosted services to be accessed by clients from remote locations' | Page 1: 'While most would assume SaaS licenses to be rather straightforward whereby clients are charged through recurring subscription fees on a pay-as-you-go basis'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software as a Service (SaaS) Business Model - A cloud computing service model that provides applications on top of PaaS and IaaS, where software is delivered via the Internet as a service with multi-tenant or multi-instance architecture, enabling software renting as an alternative to traditional perpetual licensing.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Software as a Service (SaaS), which provides applications on top of PaaS and IaaS' | Page 1: 'When the software is sold through the software as a service (SaaS) model, it facilitates a number of revenue and pricing models.' | Page 1: 'a number of studies have suggested that software renting is becoming more frequent in the new era of computing, in which software is delivered via the SaaS model' | Page 2: 'SaaS has multi-tenant or multi-instance architecture; the former refers to the situation in which a vendor hosts a single instance on a server that serves multiple customers (tenants), whereas the latter is related to the model in which a vendor hosts separate instances for each customer within shared hardware'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Cloud-based business model / SaaS-based business model. Definition: A model for enabling convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort, delivered as software-as-a-service over the Internet with subscription-based payment model.
synonyms_found: utility-like way to deliver and consume IT resources
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Abstract: 'In this paper, we present a case study of an ERP vendor for SMB (small and medium-size business) in making a transition towards a cloud-based business model.' | Page 1, Section 1: 'The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines cloud computing as "a model for enabling convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (for example, networks, servers, storage, applications, and services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service-provider interaction"' | Page 2, Section 2: 'the business model of cloud computing implies a different revenue stream: instead of relying on upfront license fee, IT vendors are now collecting periodic subscription fee'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software Business Model. Definition: The idea that describes how you create value through software, which can be a pure software product, a software-hardware combination, or a service. Service components enable securing recurring revenue but require investment in and management of operations required to deliver it.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Section 'Your Business Model and Strategy': 'Start with your business model, the idea that describes how you create value. Will that be a pure software product, such as Microsoft Windows; a software–hardware combination (consider the iPhone); or a service, such as eBay? Having a service component in your offering lets you secure recurring revenue. However, you'll also need to invest in and manage the operations required to deliver it. Thanks to the Internet and cloud computing, it's now easy to include a service component into any type of software.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Digital sustainable business models: Using digital technology to integrate ecological sustainability into the core of business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Digital Sustainable Business Model. Definition: Business models where digital technologies fundamentally change the features of the business model to integrate ecological sustainability into the core logic of the organization, encompassing value proposition (creating ecological sustainable value), value creation and delivery, and value capture while being both ecologically and economically sustainable.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Abstract: 'digital sustainable BMs (Bocken et al., 2014; Schaltegger et al., 2016), including the value proposition, value delivery, and value capture (Ritter & Lettl, 2018; Teece, 2010), those start-ups do not curb to environmental damage reactively but use digital technologies proactively to tackle global warming as an integral part of their BM.' | Page 2: 'we go beyond using digital technology to optimise production or logistics or enable remote work and implement ecological sustainability as a core logic of the organisation and its identity' | Page 4: 'The resulting digital BMs (DBMs) are defined as BMs where digital technologies fundamentally change the features of the BM and enable resource optimization'

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Freemium Business Model. Definition: An emerging business model that combines 'free' and 'premium,' offering a free basic version of the product and a fully paid version. It creates value with free products and then adds more value through premium sales or fragmented upsell products. Two main types: Bundled freemium (business adds value through premium sales with interrelated features bundled together) and Fragmented freemium (creates value with free products then adds value with many fragmented upsell products that can be sold separately).
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3, Section 2.1: 'As an emerging business model, the freemium business model has received considerable attention from business research in recent years. Freemium combines "free" and "premium," i.e., offering a free basic version of the product and a fully paid version.' | Page 7, Table 3: 'The business adds more value through one (or several) premium sales (from which it gets value)' (bundled) | 'The company creates value with free products and then adds more value with many "fragmented" upsell products' (fragmented)

responses_by_article.article_title: Strategy and business model evolution at Adobe: Competing in digital media software industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Cloud and subscription-based pricing model - A business model where customers pay recurring amounts at set times to access software products or services delivered through cloud infrastructure, replacing traditional perpetual licensing where customers purchased software for lifetime use.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Abstract: 'Why Adobe made an important yet risky strategic decision to transition from the time-tested perpetual licence price model to a cloud and subscription-based pricing model is the primary focus of this case.' | Page 6, Business model changes: 'In 2012, Adobe went from a perpetual licence-based business strategy to a monthly subscription business model' | Page 6, Revenue stream: 'Customers pay a certain amount of money at set times to access the company's product or service in the subscription business model.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Navigating the paradox of global scaling
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Replicable Innovation - A global strategy for globally scaling digital MNEs that enables rapid growth and sustained competitiveness through a virtuous cycle of identifying innovations that can be replicated throughout the organization while maintaining the global business model
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4: 'We show that globally scaling digital MNEs follow a new-to-the-literature strategy, which we label replicable innovation, to navigate these competing demands and sustain competitiveness. The replicable innovation strategy is based on a virtuous cycle that sustains competitiveness through three mechanisms'

responses_by_article.article_title: Systematic Literature Review of Monetization in Mobile App: Strategies, Trends, Challenges, and Best Practices
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Freemium - A business model that combines free and premium versions of a product, where users can access a free version with restricted functionality and a complete version that costs money but has more features and capabilities. It is a mix of the terms 'free' and 'premium'.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'The phrase "freemium" refers to two different versions of a product: a free version with restricted functionality and a complete version that costs money but has more features and capabilities. It is a mix of the terms "free" and "premium"'

responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'This paper explores the rapid growth in the public valuations of SaaS companies' | Page 1: 'Software as a Service companies, which have surged in number and value in recent years' | Page 8: 'subscription business models differ from their traditional counterparts. responses_by_article.article_title: Managing Software-as-a-Service: Pricing and operations
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS). The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines SaaS as the capability provided to the consumer of using the provider's applications running on a cloud infrastructure where the applications are accessible from various client devices and interfaces and the consumer generally does not manage or control the infrastructure.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, lines 54-59: 'The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines SaaS as the capability provided to the consumer of using the provider's applications running on a cloud infrastructure where the applications are accessible from various client devices and interfaces and the consumer generally does not manage or control the infrastructure (Mell & Grance, 2011).'

responses_by_article.article_title: Converting free users to paid subscribers in the SaaS context: The impact of marketing touchpoints, message content, and usage
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) - A business model that centrally hosts and licenses software on a subscription basis, where customers pay a monthly or annual subscription fee that is usually less expensive than the price of a perpetual license, and consumers can access the software via the Internet while SaaS vendors offer the software remotely on cloud-based hardware.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Software-as-a-service (SaaS) is a popular business model that centrally hosts and licenses software on a subscription basis. Many software companies such as Microsoft and Salesforce have adopted the SaaS model. Under the SaaS model, customers pay a monthly or annual subscription fee that is usually less expensive than the price of a perpetual license. Consumers can access the software via the Internet, while the SaaS vendors offer the software remotely on cloud-based hardware.'

The goal of platform thinking is to build a software platform that is a foundation for a new ecosystem.

responses_by_article.article_title: Competition Among Proprietary and Open-Source Software Firms: The Role of Licensing in Strategic Contribution
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: OSSg2 (Second-generation open-source) - A professional open-source business model where profit-motivated firms are driven by revenues stemming from a market for professional services, characterized by firms that typically generate the bulk of their revenues by providing complementary services around their products and own or tightly control the software code to exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service than could potential competing service providers.
synonyms_found: services-based business models built on open-source software
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'This professional open-source business model, where profit-motivated firms are driven by revenues stemming from a market for professional services, is not a new one... Watson et al. (2008, p.43) refer to this type of OSS business model as second-generation open-source or OSSg2, characterized by firms that typically generate the bulk of their revenues by providing complementary services around their products and own or tightly control the software code and can exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service than could potential competing service providers.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Hypothesis-driven Adaptation of Business Models based on Product Line Engineering
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Business Model Decision Line (BMDL) - A concept that applies the engineering process of Software Product Lines (SPLs) to the structure of the Business Model Canvas (BMC) to support the process of business model adaptation by matching business domain knowledge in the form of a feature model with customer needs to derive hypotheses about the business model together with experiments for validation.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'We call this concept a Business Model Decision Line (BMDL). The BMDL matches business domain knowledge in the form of a feature model with customer needs to derive hypotheses about the business model together with experiments for validation.'

responses_by_article.article_title: E-business evolution: an analysis of mobile applications' business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Mobile applications business models. The article defines business model as how a company creates and captures value, specifically studying mobile applications (mobile software accessible by mobile devices that allow access to products/services from anywhere, cutting spatial and timely barriers to value delivery). The study identifies four typologies: content-oriented (production and provision of online content through user-friendly platforms), commerce-oriented (trading aspects of online transactions), context-oriented (structuring existing information to help users find services), and connection-oriented (offering virtual spaces for online networks).
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'The business model of a company mainly depicts how it creates and captures value' | Page 2: 'mobile applications, i.e. softwares accessible by mobile devices that allow access to a series of products/services from anywhere and by anyone, cutting the spatial and timely barriers to the delivery of value for customers' | Page 3: 'Wirtz, Schilke, and Ullrich (2010), in recognising the new challenges and opportunities of the new digital era seminally defined four general typologies of business model in terms of value creation: (i) content-oriented, focused on the production and provision of online content through user-friendly platforms (e.g. The Economist online) almost relying on advertising or premium fees as revenue streams; (ii) commerce-oriented, focused on the trading aspects of online transactions using online media (e.g. eBay), so they rely on commissions as revenue streams; (iii) context-oriented, focused on structuring already existent information in order to help Internet users find the service that satisfies their needs (e.g. Yahoo), those almost rely on advertising as revenue streams; (iv) connection-oriented, focused on offering virtual spaces that enable participants to join online networks (e.g. Facebook) that usually pay a subscription for those.'

responses_by_article.article_title: A Study on Cloud-Based Software Marketing Strategies Using Cloud Marketplace
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Cloud Marketplace Model - A software distribution model where Cloud Service Providers (CSPs) build marketplaces where software can be easily used by customers and software developers can achieve global sales at lower costs than conventional software distribution methods by registering their own software without a need to build separate applications and distribution services.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Cloud service providers (CSPs) try to build a marketplace where software can be easily used for their customers and try to acquire a wide variety of software developers. Software developers can achieve global sales at lower costs than conventional software distribution methods by registering their own software in their marketplaces without a need to build separate applications and distribution services.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Software as a service: Lessons from the video game industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Games-as-a-Service (GaaS): A business model where all the software needed to play the game is located on an external server, essentially a variant of SaaS. The model allows developers to update games on the fly and continually add new content, keeping games evolving rather than finished products.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'The provision of multiplayer and standalone games via the internet —essentially a variant of SaaS —has led to the growth of a distinct games-as-a-service (GaaS) business model, where all the software needed to play the game is located on an external server' | Page 2: 'With the GaaS model, they can update a game on the fly —that is, release as many updates as they want, whenever they want —allowing all players to receive them as soon as they connect to the server. With GaaS-based games, players never really finish a game because it keeps evolving.'

responses_by_article.article_title: The SaaS Payoff: Measuring the Business Value of Provisioning Software-as-a-Service Technologies
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS). SaaS is a cloud computing service model where IT service providers provision virtualised software-based solutions from centralised locations with the capability to automatically scale-up and down dynamically based on demand for computational resources, delivered to customers typically through multi-tenant environments.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Creating and capturing value with new digital technologies such as cloud computing...the impact of Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) on incumbent IT supply-side organisations' | Page 7: 'SaaS has facilitated (1) the provision of virtualised SaaS-based solutions from a centralised location which possess the capability to automatically scale-up and down dynamically based on the demand for computational resources'

responses_by_article.article_title: Making a Business Out of (Predictive Application Management in) the Fog
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Two business models are presented: (1) License-based Business Model: A model where Asset Manufacturers pay yearly license fees to access and integrate predictive application management services into their ecosystems. (2) Freemium Business Model: A model that directly targets Application Operators with free and paid tiers, where free customers have limitations (bounded monthly predictions, lower quality results, no support) and paying customers access complete services with premium support.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 6, Section III-A: 'Asset Manufacturers should pay yearly license fees (Revenue Streams) to access the predictive application management service and to include it in their ecosystems (Value Proposition)' | Page 6, Section III-B: 'freemium models require the costs of non-paying customers to be covered by another part of the business model or by another Customer Segment. We, therefore, split Application Operators into two segments, i.e. free and subscribing customers. Paying customers will have access to the complete version of the considered predictive application management service and to premium customer support. On the contrary, free customers will have limitations to their accounts, e.g. bounded number of monthly predictions, lower quality results, no access to the support service.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Synergies between App-Based Car-Related Shared Mobility Services for the Development of More Profitable Business Models
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: App-based car-related shared mobility services. Definition: Business models that provide on-demand transportation services through mobile applications, divided into three main types: ride-sourcing (ride-hailing and ridesharing) and vehicle sharing (carsharing), which changed urban mobility from a limited transportation offer to a scenario full of new players offering mobility-on-demand in different ways.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'These new mobility business models have changed the urban mobility sector from a limited transportation offer to a scenario full of new players offering mobility-on-demand in different ways.' | Page 2: 'we divide the shared mobility business models into two main areas: ride-sourcing, which refers to the services of ride-hailing and ridesharing; and vehicle sharing, which is based on renting vehicles for short periods of time.'

responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Some smaller vendors utilized a free distribution system (Free/Open Source ERP, FOS-ERP) for their source code, relying on various business models for corporate success.' | Page 2: 'Nomenclature [...] FOS-ERP free open source ERP software' | Page 1: 'FOS-ERP can be community based, or sponsored by some organization'

responses_by_article.article_title: Analysis of Freemium Business Model Considering Network Externalities and Consumer Uncertainty
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Freemium model. Definition: A business model where companies provide both a free basic version and a paid premium version for a service or product to customers. The free version can reduce customer uncertainty regarding the evaluation of the commercial software and make use of network effect to improve the firm's profit.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'An emerging business model increasingly used by companies in the online software market is to provide both a free basic version and a paid premium version for a service or a product to customers. Such a setting is often called freemium model. The existence of the free version can reduce the customer uncertainty regarding the evaluation of the commercial software and make use of network effect to improve the firm's profit.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Investigating e-business models' value retention for start-ups: The moderating role of venture capital investment intensity
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: The article presents four e-business models: (1) Novelty-centred business model: referring to novel ways of conducting economic exchanges among various participants; (2) Efficiency-centred business model: referring to means of gaining transaction efficiency among its transaction partners; (3) Lock-in-centred business model: concerning the means to retain engagement with existing transaction partners by creating switching costs or incentives; (4) Complementarity-centred business model: as the method to increase the transactions by creating greater complementarities in activities and among different partners in the market.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Four different themes in e-business models are classified by Amit and Zott (2001): novelty-centred business model referring to novel ways of conducting economic exchanges among various participants; efficiency-centred business model referring to means of gaining transaction efficiency among its transaction partners; lock-in-centred business model concerning the means to retain engagement with existing transaction partners by creating switching costs or incentives; complementarity-centred business model as the method to increase the transactions by creating greater complementarities in activities and among different partners in the market.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Growth of a platform business model as an entrepreneurial ecosystem and its effects on regional development
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Platform business model: A business model where platforms provide architectures to combine internal and external innovations in ways that create value throughout the chain of activities that deliver useful technology to the market. The article examines both Open Business Model (OBM) platforms and supplier Open Innovation (OI) platforms as types of platform business models.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4: 'Platforms provide architectures to combine internal and external innovations in ways that create value throughout the chain of activities that deliver useful technology to the market' | Page 6: 'customer platforms are similar to OBMs (Chesbrough, 2010, 2012, 2013). OBMs allow ideas to travel from invention to commercialization through at least two different companies and not just through a hosting company.' | Page 6: 'supplier platform triggers supplier-based OI or supplier OI'

responses_by_article.article_title: Developing enterprise social software in China: insights from Mingdao
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: SaaS (Software as a Service) delivery model for Enterprise Social Software (ESS): A cloud-computing-enabled service model that provides enterprise social collaboration platform applications and solutions via real-time network. The platform enables internal management communication, project management, team collaboration, and knowledge management through an enterprise social network, similar to an internal version of Facebook.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'according to the industry classification, Mingdao provides cloud computing services. The cloud computing service [delivery] model can be divided into SaaS (Software as a Service), PaaS (Platform as a Service), and IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service)...The new Mingdao platform will also be a standard SaaS.' | Page 3: 'Mingdao will be an enterprise social collaboration platform...to achieve internal management communication, project management, team collaboration, and knowledge management and other tasks, somewhat similar to 'the internal' version of Facebook.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Open source - Is it an alternative to intellectual property?
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Open Source Business Model: A model where a community of individuals makes contributions to a body of knowledge through peer-review systems, facilitated by distinctive licensing that uses property rights to build an environment with lesser restrictions on access and use. The model involves unpaid volunteers contributing creations to an intermediary (company or organization) which facilitates inspection, compilation and releases improved versions. Three main variations: (1) Reciprocal License Model (copyleft-based, service-oriented revenue from professional services), (2) Academic License Model (permissive licenses allowing proprietary derivatives, revenue from licensing and services), (3) Dual Business Model (offering both open source and proprietary licenses, revenue mainly from license fees).
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'In open source, a community of individuals makes contributions to a body of knowledge, sets up peer-review systems for quality control and then nurtures and nourishes that body of knowledge' | Page 5-6: 'The basic characteristic of the open source method of software development is that the community of unpaid volunteers contributes creations to a community leader, the intermediary, which is often an incorporated company or organization. This community leader in turn facilitates the inspection and compilation of individual contributions and then releases the collective creation as an improved version' | Page 10: 'Companies that rely on "reciprocal licenses", based on copyleft will have their revenues coming from professional services..."Academic licenses", on the other hand, enable companies to generate revenue from both licensing and professional services...The "Dual Business model" allows companies to give customers the choice of two licensing models: open source or proprietary/commercial'

responses_by_article.article_title: Difficult Business Models of Digital Business Platforms for Health Data: A Framework for Evaluation of the Ecosystem Viability
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Digital Business Platform (or Multi-sided Platform/Multi-sided Business Platform). Definition: A business model pattern where platforms bring together two or more distinct but interdependent groups of customers and create value by facilitating interactions between the different groups, specifically by enabling value exchange between producing peers and consuming peers through transactions.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'For evaluation of the viability of the cross-organizational integration platform we look at the platform as a business model pattern: multi-sided business platform. Multi-sided platforms bring together two or more distinct but interdependent groups of customers and create value by facilitating interactions between the different groups' | Page 2: 'The purpose of Digital Business Platforms is to create value by enabling value exchange between two groups, the producing peers and the consuming peers, resulting in a business transaction'

responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: E-invoicing Service Provider Model - A business model where a professional third party (service provider or e-invoicing platform) manages the e-invoice transfer process by translating invoice data provided by the issuer into the format suitable for the recipient, guaranteeing essential legal requirements, authenticity, and data integrity.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4: 'The service provider model is embraced when supplier or buyer wishes to buy e-invoice issuing or receiving from a professional third party, referred to as service provider (or e-invoicing platform). The service provider manages the e-invoice transfer process by translating invoice data provided by the issuer into the format suitable for the recipient. The service provider guarantees essential legal requirements, authenticity, and data integrity.' | Page 4: 'XML-based invoicing systems provide the possibility for interoperable infrastructures enabling many-to-many service provider models instead of partner-specific point-to-point connections between suppliers and buyers'

responses_by_article.article_title: Give Away Your Digital Services: Leveraging Big Data to Capture Value
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Free-to-consumers business model based on big data and two-sided markets. Definition: A business model where companies offer digital services for free to consumers while capturing value from user-generated data through three strategies: enhanced advertising (using data to target ads), e-ethnography (using data to improve internal products/services), and data trading (selling user data to third parties).
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'New models that capture the value embedded in the data generated by digital services may make it viable for companies to offer those services for free' | Page 2: 'companies relying on a free-to-consumers business model' | Page 5: 'Our analysis suggested three possible strategies for leveraging big data, which we've called enhanced advertising, e-ethnography, and data trading' | Page 2: 'Through a case study analysis, we show how leveraging a two-sided structure can enable companies to capture value from user-sourced data, enabling a sustainable free-to-consumers business model'

responses_by_article.article_title: Making Digital Freemium Business Models a Success: Predicting Customers' Lifetime Value via Initial Purchase Information
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Freemium (also known as 'free to play' in gaming industry). Definition: A pricing model where users can access services for free and use them as long as they like at no cost, but only a minority of users become paying customers. Companies suppress entry barriers to attract a much larger audience than paid services do.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'In this context, the freemium pricing model (also known as 'free to play' in the gaming industry) has gained increasing attention. In recent years, freemium has become the dominant pricing strategy for software, games, and social network apps' | Page 1: 'Users can access such services for free, and usually use them as long as they like at no cost. Wagner et al. (2014) describe the freemium business model as a promising solution for content providers to earn money from users who have a 'for free' mentality. It allows companies to suppress entry barriers and thus to attract a much larger audience than paid services do. However, only a minority of such users actually become paying customers.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Understanding the influence of absorptive capacity and ambidexterity on the process of business model change – the case of on-premise and cloud-computing software
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Software as a Service (SaaS) / Cloud-computing business model. Definition: An on-demand software delivery service that offers ubiquitous access to applications through the internet, sharing a pool of common resources managed by SaaS providers, provided on a pay-per-use basis. In contrast to the traditional on-premise license model where customers purchase and operate software on their own IT infrastructure.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Around 15% of the global cloud-computing market comprises Software as a Service (SaaS), an on-demand software delivery service that offers ubiquitous access to applications and shares a pool of common resources managed by SaaS providers' | Page 3: 'With the rise of SaaS in 2000, new business model designs have emerged, delivering single ERP functionalities on demand through the internet' | Page 3: 'Using SaaS enables companies to focus on core competencies, because they are relieved of the burden of financing, managing and maintaining their own IT infrastructures. Because services are provided on a pay-per-use basis, SaaS allows for the shifting of capital expenditures to operational expenditures.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Cloud computing / Software-as-a-Service (SaaS). Definition: A model for enabling convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (networks, servers, storage, applications, services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort. Cloud-based customer relationship management software delivered over the Internet, with pay-as-you-go or subscription-based payment model.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines cloud computing as "a model for enabling convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (for example, networks, servers, storage, applications, and services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service-provider interaction"' | Page 1: 'software-as-a service (SaaS) (e.g. Salesforce.com cloud-based customer relationship management software delivered over the Internet)' | Page 2: 'the pay-as-you-go or subscription-based payment model'

responses_by_article.article_title: Business models and opportunity creation: How IT entrepreneurs create and develop business models under uncertainty
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Cloud gaming platform / Games-on-demand service. Definition: An interactive cloud gaming platform where games are run on cloud servers instead of being installed on user devices. The platform transmits game content as MPEG stream to end-user devices over broadband network, while devices display the game and transmit user commands back to game servers. This enables bringing PC and console games to players through cloud environment without requiring powerful hardware on client side.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 9: 'The case firm, G-cluster, develops interactive cloud gaming platforms and games-on-demand services. The business concept of G-cluster was based on what was (in 2000) an entirely new way to provide PC and console games to players. Traditionally, games are installed on a computer or a game console, which runs the game. In the G-cluster business model, by contrast, games are run on a cloud platform. The platform is operated by the game servers that transmit the game content as an MPEG stream to the devices of end-users, over the broadband network. The client devices receive the stream, display the game and transmit users' commands back to the game servers.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Revenue models, in-app purchase, and the app performance: Evidence from Apple's App Store and Google Play
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Three software business models are presented: (1) Free revenue model: releasing the app for free and monetizing by means of advertising and data selling; (2) Paid revenue model: marketing only paid apps and monetizing by means of app sales; (3) Freemium revenue model: offering both free and paid app versions, where a low valuable version with ads and limited/time-expiring functionalities is offered for free, and users can upgrade upon payment to the high valuable version.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'We can identify at least three main models utilized by developers in the app stores. First, some developers adopt a free app strategy, releasing the app for free, and mostly aim at monetizing by means of advertising and, to less extent, through non-personally identifiable data selling. We refer to it as a free revenue model. Second, other developers market only paid apps and mostly aim at monetizing by means of app sales. We refer to this option as a paid revenue model. Finally, some other developers combine "free" and "paid" models, by offering both free and paid app versions. Under this model, a low valuable version, which may include ads and has limited or time-expiring functionalities/features, is offered for free... We refer to this option as a freemium revenue model'

responses_by_article.article_title: Commercialization of Composite Software Resulting from Collaborative Research
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Inter-company business model for composite software based on loose partnerships: A business model where independent complementary software providers collaboratively offer a composite software solution based on loose market collaboration, operating as a value network (VN) or software ecosystem (SECO). The model involves autonomous units that operate together in a framework of common principles and service level agreements to deliver value to customers without requiring joint ventures, binding contracts, or license purchases among partners.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Thus, flexible business models are required that are based on loose partnerships among involved companies, but still enable a common presence on the market' | Page 4: 'the objective of the research was specified as follows: to develop generic design artefacts (i.e. guidelines) for development of inter-company business models for composite software based on loose partnerships of independent software providers' | Page 5: 'VN can be considered as a set of relatively autonomous units that can be managed independently but operate together in a framework of common principles and service level agreements (SLA) in order to deliver the value to customers'

responses_by_article.article_title: Business Models for Cloud Computing: Experiences from Developing Modeling & Simulation as a Service Applications in Industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Modeling & Simulation as a Service (MSaaS) business model. Definition: A cloud-based service delivery model that enables simulation software vendors and providers to offer simulation applications through the cloud to end-users, allowing users to consume simulation services without having to install or maintain simulation software locally, with the ability to scale up seamlessly as the number of end-users and complexity of simulation tasks increase.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Modeling & Simulation as a Service (MSaaS) therefore enables simulation software vendors and providers to offer simulation applications through the cloud to their end-users. responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Decentralized SaaS Business Model - A distributed business model where local servers are independent business entities that compete with each other to maximize their own profit while providing similar services/applications to customers, as an alternative to centralized SaaS models to avoid single-point-of-failure problems and investment/management issues.

responses_by_article.article_title: The relationship between Open Innovation and Strategy: data-driven analysis of the Mobile Value Services Industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Open Innovation - a model allowing the commercialization of both the ideas of a company as well as ideas coming from other firms
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Open innovation was originally defined as "a model allowing the commercialization of both the ideas of a company as well as ideas coming from other firms" [1] [2]'

responses_by_article.article_title: Open-Source Software Entrepreneurial Business Modelling
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Open-Source Software Entrepreneurial Business Modelling (OSS_EBM) - A conceptual tool that aims to be useful in entrepreneurial planning and strategic management of open source ventures. Specifically tailored for the high-tech software business, the OSS_EBM framework enables high-tech strategists and entrepreneurs to describe, design, challenge, invent, brainstorm, pivot, analyze and improve open-source business models.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Built on top of established business modelling frameworks, the Open-Source Software Entrepreneurial Business Modelling (OSS_EBM) can be a useful strategic management and entrepreneurial tool. It enables strategists and entrepreneurs to describe, design, challenge, invent, brainstorm, pivot, analyze and improve upon open-source business models.' | Page 2: 'Specifically tailored for the high-tech software business, the OSS_EBM framework enables high-tech strategists and entrepreneurs to describe, design, challenge, invent, brainstorm, pivot, analyze and improve open-source business models.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
responses_by_article.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Platform as a Service (PaaS) - Software platforms that have primarily been discussed in the context of cloud computing, representing the middle layer connecting IaaS and SaaS cloud layers, facilitating the development, testing, and management of software components, as well as knowledge exchange between developers
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2, Section 2.2: 'Platform as a Service. Platforms in the software industry are defined as "… the extensible codebase of a software-based system that provides core functionality shared by the modules that interoperate with it and the interfaces through which they interoperate" [1]. PaaS refers to software platforms that have primarily been discussed in the context of cloud computing. According to the most cited architectural concepts of cloud computing, PaaS represents the middle layer, connecting the IaaS and SaaS cloud layers [20], [21], [22]. Based on a systematic literature review, [23] describe PaaS as an execution environment in which external developers deploy and run their complementary components and applications. PaaS facilitates the development, testing, and management of software components, as well as knowledge exchange between developers.'
